Sentences about perception, animals, verb tenses Sonny Davis and Vina Smith 2010 Unpublished (recorded by Andrew Garrett and Line Mikkelsen on October 25, 2010)
tá
ni thítiv .
ta nithitiv.
I heard it.
tá
ni thítiv .
ta nithitiv.
I heard it.
tá
nu thítiv .
ta nuthitiv.
We all heard it.
tá

pa púsihich .
ta nithitiv papusihich.

tá

pa púsihich .
ta nimah papusihich.

pa púsihich .

nu mah .
iim ta numah.

iim
tá
nu mah .
iim ta numah.

tá
ni mah .
ta nimah.
I see it.
tá
nu mah .
ta numah.
We all see it.
ni máh eesh .
nimaheesh.
I will see it.
pa púsihich
îin
tá
ná mah .
papusihich iin ta namah.
The cat sees me. This use of îin doesn't fit dictionary description regarding personal inflection on following verb.
pa púsihich
u máh tih
iim .
papusihich umahtih iim.
The cat sees you. Glottalization in the personal inflection - hesitation? 3sg/2sg is supposed to trigger 'i-...-ap
pa púsihich
iim
t u mah .
papusihich iim tumah.
The cat sees you.

um .

Do you have lots of cats? um after each word; unexpected use of this verb with plural object - WB has tâaraha for have with plural objects

pa nini púsihich .
taay paninipusihich.
I have lots of cats.

uum

pa púsihich
u thiiná tih .

pa púsihich

I hear the cat No translation offered; v~m in verb root following WB:G342

ni thítiim ti
u pakurîihvu tih .
papusihich nithitiimti upakuriihvutih.
I hear the cat purring. v~m in verb root following WB:G342; tih does not condition lengthening of final syllable of stem because stem is vowel final
pa púsihich
u pakurîihvu tih .
papusihich upakuriihvutih.

ní muus tih
uum
pa púsihich
u 'áam tih .
nimuustih uum papusihich u'aamtih.
I am looking at the cat eating.
pa púsihich
u 'áam tih .
papusihich u'aamtih.

pa púsihich
u 'áam tih .
papusihich u'aamtih.

pa púsihich
íp
t u 'áv at .
papusihich ip tu'avat.

púsihich
ipít

pa púsihich
tá

I'm touching the cat.

tá

papusihich ta na'afish.
The cat is touching me. na- fails to attract acute accent because stem has acute accent of the fixed type (due to VcV shape)
pa púsihich
tá
kun váthiv .
papusihich ta kunvathiv.
The cats are fighting. tá sounds more like tu here, but another repetition clearly has tá.
tá
ni thítiv
pa yupsítanach
u xrára tih .
ta nithitiv payupsitanach uxraratih.
I hear the baby crying.
yáxa
pa púsihich .
yaxa papusihich.
Look at the cat!
fâat
u kupavêenahi .
faat ukupaveenahi.
What is it doing? verb can be broken down into: kupa-...-aha 'modal' (G732), vêen 'to pray' (perh. orig. 'to do')
tá
ni thítiv
pa púsihich
îikam .
ta nithitiv papusihich iikam.
I hear the cat outside.

pa púsihich
îikam
u vathíiv tih .
ta nithitiv papusihich iikam uvathiivtih.
I hear the cats fighting outside.

púsihich
tá
ni mah .
taay pusihich ta nimah.
I see lots of cats.
púfaat
pa púsihich .
pufaat papusihich.
There are no cats.
púfaat
pa púsihich .
pufaat papusihich.
There are no cats.
arara chúupha
nuu
payêem
nu chúupi tih .
ararachuupha nuu payeem nuchuupitih.
We are talking our Indian language now. The vowel in nuu doesn't sound long, but nuu seems the best parse

koovúra
kun ivyíhuk .
yanava koovura kunivyihuk.
Look they all came!

t óo kfuk
súpaah .
yanava pakuusrah tookfuk supaah.
Look the sun is getting up. Is "tóo kfuk súpaah" the right parse?
ta ni
kúnish
ni thítiv
pa chishíih
p oo hyíiv tih .
tani kunish nithitiv pachishiih poohyiivtih.
I heard the dog barking. What is tani? What is kunish doing here?
yánava
pa chishíih
p oo hyíiv tih .
yanava pachishiih poohyiivtih.
The dogs are barking. -tih conditions vowel lengthening in the final syllable of verb root and accute accent on that vowel by special progressive accentuation.
u hyíiv tih .
uhyiivtih.
It is barking.
yupthúkirar
u xrára tih .
yupthukirar uxraratih.
A mountain lion is crying.
vírusur
uum
taay
p oo xrúunha tih .
virusur uum taay pooxruunhatih.
The bear is growling a lot.
súva nik
tá
ni mah .
suvanik ta nimah.
I see it later on (?)
súva nik
nu máh eesh .
suvanik numaheesh.
I will see you later.
nu
ni 'áasish
ni kyív it
xás
vúra
fâatva
ni thítiv .
nu ni'aasish nikyivit xas vura faatva nithitiv.
When I was sleeping I heard something. What is nu? Why two inflected verbs in a row? Is it some kind of complex predicate? "I fall down" doesn't really make sense semantically. Could it be "nikik" (a little bit) + something?
taahkúnish
pa mu 'ífunih .
taahkunish pamu'ifunih.
Her hair is white.
Vina
mu 'ífuni
uum
taahkúnish .
Vina mu'ifuni uum taahkunish.
Vina has white hair.
hôoy
uum
pa 'ikxáramkunish
púsihich .
hooy uum pa'ikxaramkunish pusihich.
Where is the black cat? initial ik- of 2240 is somewhat reduced
Sentences about driving and directions Sonny Davis and Vina Smith 2010 Unpublished (recorded by Andrew Garrett and Line Mikkelsen on October 25, 2010)

2011 Unpublished (recorded by Andrew Garrett, Line Mikkelsen, and Tammy Stark on January 29, 2011)

I ate acorn soup. This example does not use the final -at past suffix, at least, it is completely inaudible

íp
ni 'áv at .
xuun ip ni'avat.
I ate acorn soup. Is xuun accented? If so, why? (It shouldn't -- may just be prosodic?) This example uses the final -at past marker

This text retains Harrington's spelling in some cases. For example, writing double consonants, writing a small y and w for consonants that have these sounds following them, and writing some small words together as one word. He thought: "I am going to look in!" ti (tîi) written as prefix on following word Harrington: "It was always a man's duty to remove and replace the board that covers the roofhole of the living-house. A man came from the sweathouse early to do this. He never looked in since the women folks slept without their skirts on; If a man looked in he would soon die: Puxxár imyáahtihara, pootnuupníhtihaak chanchaaksúrak, he would not live long if he peeked through the living-house roofhole. But Coyote again cuts custom."

"Speech to Karuk Tribal Council" William Bright
2004 Unpublished (Recorded by Susan Gehr on February 26th, 2004) WB-01 A video of Bright's speech is available here. Bright states that Vina Smith and Violet Super helped him compose this speech.

I'm very happy that I'm here in Orleans, that I'm here with all of you.

pi'eep, paniyaan'iiftihanhaak, pa'ook karuk veethivthaaneen pishiich ni'uumhaak, papanamniik pishiich ni'uumhaak, naa vura xakitrahyar karu yitha harinay kich tanikrii.
Long ago, when I was young, when I first came to Karuk country, when I first came to Orleans, I was only 21 years old. Bright says pananiyáan'iiftihanhaak, but surely meant only to say paniyáan'iiftihanhaak. Use of unexpected form of -ahaak on uum verbs. Should be uumahaak, but he has uumhaak. He writes no accent on xakitrahyar. The online dictionary has the accent like this: xakitráhyar.

I didn't know anything! Use of nominal allomorph of ANC tense (-hanik) rather than expected verbal allomorph (-anik).

vúra

kuna vura pa'ararakeevriikshas, pa'ararapihniichas, pananikaruk va'arareefyiivshas koovura neepsharavrik.
But the Karuk old women, the Karuk old men, my Karuk friends, they all helped me. Vowel coalescence in word in va'araréefyiivshas indicates that ifyiiv rather than afyiiv as expected is the root meaning "friend." In the main verb, na- prefix is for 3sg on 1sg, but the agent is clearly 3pl.

And so I slowly learned the Indian language, the Indian customs, the Indian stories.

Now I myself am an old man, I'm 75 years old.

But I've come back here again, I'm visiting my friends, and I'm still learning the Karuk language.

He kicked it out from kátiphirak. Bright: "kátiphirak is a village-site across-stream from Camp Creek."

tuyvuk'uuth upiytuuykar.
He kicked it out from túuyvuk. Bright: "túuyvuk is a village-site at Ullathorne Creek, below Camp Creek. This passage accounts for the origin of the river-bars at the sites named."

kupánakanakana. Young brodiaea plant, you must come up quickly. Bright: "This word is used only to end the telling of a myth. It is sometimes followed, as in this case, by a short prayer for food, reflecting the fact that myths were originally told only in the winter, when food was scarce."

xúriha .

He was so thin, he was hungry. Bright: "The shift here from first to third person reference is difficult to account for. It may be that sentences 68 through 72 are conceived of as being spoken by Coyote."

1957 William Bright, The Karok Language (1957), pp. 198-201, Text 13 "Karok audio recordings" (1949), California Language Archive, Item LA 78, Segment 8 Bright: "The content of this story suggests that it is actually a medicine formula, to be recited by gamblers for good luck. "ayiyihanijanee hanijaaneeya." "ayiyihanijanee hanijaaneeya." "ayiyihanijanee hanijaaneeya." Bright: "Coyote's song consists of these meaningless syllables, repeated over and over. No significant pitch or stress can be determined for this sequence; the word-division which is written indicates the phrasing of the melody, rather than a juncture phoneme. The phone 'j,' which has not been found in any other Karuk material, is like that in English 'judge.'"

á 'iknêechhan
pirishkâarim
mu hrôoha .
a'ikneechhan pirishkaarim muhrooha. Duck Hawk's wife was Grizzly Bear. In the text, Bright writes Duck Hawk as á'iknêechhan, but the dictionary has as its form a'iknêechhan.
ka'tim'îin
kun 'iin .
ka'tim'iin kun'iin. They lived in Katimin.
á 'iknêechhan
pa mu 'îin
u kyâa nik .
a'ikneechhan pamu'iin ukyaanik. Duck Hawk made his falls (there).
xás
pa 'áraar
p oo 'îin hi ti
víri va
mu súrukam
kun 'írunaa tih .
xas pa'araar poo'iinhiti viriva musurukam kun'irunaatih. And the people traveled behind where the falls were. Bright: "That is, the falls were so high, and their top jutted out so far, that it was possible to cross the river by walking underneath them."
xás
u xús
" tishráam
kan vâaram i ."
xas uxus "tishraam kanvaarami." And he thought, "Let me go to Scott Valley."
xás
káan
askitávaan
u tápkuup .
xas kaan askitavaan utapkuup. He liked a woman there.
u 'ípak
kúkuum .
u'ipak kukuum. He came back again.
vúra
u pvâaram .
vura upvaaram. He went away again.
vúra
xára
t u sínmoo .
vura xara tusinmoo. He was away for a long time.
pâanpay
pirishkâarim
t u thítiv
" káan
t u 'iimníhva ."
paanpay pirishkaarim tuthitiv "kaan tu'iimnihva." Finally Grizzly Bear heard he was having a love affair there.
xás
kóova
ú xviipha ,
pa 'îin
u páktaapsip .
xas koova uxviipha, pa'iin upaktaapsip. And she was so mad, she tipped the falls up on one end. Bright: "This is the origin of á'uuyich, the hill known in English as Sugarloaf. As stated in sentence 26, this hill is the present-day home of Duck Hawk; see Kroeber, 1946, pp.13-14."
xás
u pvâaram .
xas upvaaram. Then she went away.
káruma
á 'iknêechhan
u 'ípahoo tih .
karuma a'ikneechhan u'ipahootih. The fact was, Duck Hawk was coming back.
tishravará'iivreer
t u p ikfúkuvraa .
tishravara'iivreer tupikfukuvraa. He came over Etna Mountain.
pa mu 'îin
hôoy
ník
ú xaak tih .
pamu'iin hooy
nik uxaaktih. There was no sound of his falls. Bright: "Lit., 'Where were his falls soundig somewhat?' This is an instance of the way in which Karuk uses a question stylistically to express a negative."
vúra
vaa
u 'ípahoo tih .
vura vaa u'ipahootih. He was coming back like that.
asa'urúh'iivreen
u p itshîiprin .
asa'uruh'iivreen upitshiiprin. He caught sight of it at asa'urúh'iivreen (a hill near Katimin).
" yáh naa ,
pa nani 'îin

viriva kuma'ii kunipeenti "xuux mukrivruhvanamich." For that reason they call it "xuux's little rolling-place." Bright: "Duck Hawk's wife is here called xuux; this name designates an extinct and possibly only legendary animal, identified by some informants with the grizzly bear and by others with the African lion."

Bright: "The verb tákuk, translated 'to clean out' in sentence 3, refers to the process of cutting off the projecting sticks on the inside of a basket, after the actual weaving is finished. The heroine, not having time to do this, put her cap on inside out; as a result, the cups of tan oak acorns are prickly, rather than smooth."

"The Creation of Eels" Nettie Reuben
1957 William Bright, The Karok Language (1957), pp. 242-243, Text 41 Bright: "This is the only story about Across-the-Water-Widower which I was able to record; one other Karuk story about him appears in Harrington, 1032a, pp.67-72. A character with a similar name is much more prominent in the mythology of the Yurok and the Hupa; cf. Kroeber, 1925, pp.73 and 134."

Bright: "Another informant offered additional information: Before Across-the-Water-Widower's meeting with Tick, men (or rather, male ikxaréeyavs) had penises long enough to wrap several times around their necks, and could copulate with a woman on the other side of the river."

tuus ukuphaanik. Mockingbird did it. Bright: "This story, if it can actually be called that, is based on the observation that the mockingbird arrives on the Klamath in the summer, at the beginning of salmon season, and leaves in the fall. The swamp robin arrives in the fall, at the beginning of acorn season, and leaves again in the spring."
"Why Lightning Strikes Trees" Nettie Reuben

However, he became tired and lay down to sleep at his first fire, only a short distance from Katimin; cf. Kroeber and Gifford, pp. 116 and 123. The present text was recorded under adverse conditions and is hardly more than a fragment of the complete story."

I climb up there on the Ridge of Long Acorn-Meats Young-Woman. Bright: "According to Kroeber and Gifford, p. 27, xurishaxara'ifápiit, literally 'young woman of long acorn meats,' is 'a word of respect for panther... The regular word is Pirishkarim, but no one uses it lest Panther be angered.' There is evidently some confusion here; the 'regular word' for the panther, i.e., the mountain lion, is yupthúkirar, and this animal is personified as masculine. pirishkâarim, on the other hand, is the 'regular word' for the grizzly bear, which is sometimes identified by the Indians with the African lion, and which is personified as feminine."

Bright: "'Tossel' is what English-speaking Karok call the tákasar or double-ball used in their shinny game; it consists of two short sticks connected by a thong. Use of kun- in this sentence and the following I think is for literary effect, to make it seem like there are many antagonists or to obscure him. I have glossed the subject as "they" to try and preserve this.

p eeshnanich 'íshiip .
vaa uum papaaxkivtihan uum peekpihan'ishiip karu peeshnanich'ishiip.
The winners were the strongest and the swiftest. Bright: "Regarding this game, see Goddard, pp.60-61, and plate 19, figures 3 and 4. Evidently each of the three pairs of players described in the present text consisted of one man from each team. After the middle pair had put the tossel in play, the other pairs would also wrestle, each man trying to keep his opponent from reaching the tossel. In sentences 27 and 28, the terms payu'kúkam 'the downriver side' and paka'kúkam 'the upriver side' evidently do not refer to the pairs of opponents at downriver and upriver ends of the field, but to the downriver and upriver teams, respectively. The course of play is not necessarily, of course, the exact one described in the present text."
"Work Contests" Nettie Reuben
1957 William Bright, The Karok Language (1957), pp. 292-293, Text 79

1957 William Bright, The Karok Language (1957), pp. 294-297, Text 83 Bright: "The informant had served as ifuthkam'ahóovaan or junior priestess, and dictated this text from the memory of her experience."
